textBlocks.text:
Likely both the most challenging, and the most interesting coding project I have worked on to date - unlikely as this might sound: A configurator for wedding rings.

This project, a complete re-imagining of [Henrich & Denzel](https://www.henrich-denzel.com/)'s old ['Design Your Ring'](https://www.design-your-ring.com/) configurator, posed many, many interesting challenges in the 3D space - and resulted in equally many iteration cycles.
We choose to realize the project - which also included a shop front - using ***react***, ***react-three-fiber***, as well as adjacent libraries.

In parallel, Vragments is developing a new Product Management System for Henrich & Denzel, and interaction between the ring-configurator and the PMS via API took on an increasingly large role.

Check out the currently deployed version under 'View Live' above.

Initially, our interpretation of the project's scope was limited to loading pre-modeled meshes (as *gltf* files, or more specifically: compressed *glb* files). These would ostensibly be scaled in width and diameter and look okay, within certain limits.

Later on, the limits of scaling such meshes became apparent, and we had to return to the drawing board.

While the capability to load individual rings as *GLTF* would be kept for certain rings, we would now create ring meshes on the fly, extruding 2d splines - loaded from DXF files - along a circular curve or along a provided curve of different shape.

For this, I needed to dust off an older library allowing parsing of the *DXF* files which our client exported, and also had to extend **three.js**'s *ExtrudeGeometry* class to allow for completely closed meshes.

A customer could now initially choose a ring's width and circumference, and the mesh displayed on-screen would be created precisely according the input values, limited by constraints set in the backend.

In order to realize all capabilities the client asked for, we had to then implement more complex extrusion options for the ring profiles.

This allowed for several colors/alloys on one single ring mesh by splitting the extrusion profiles according to segmentation values, also coming from the backend.

Obviously material management was an important part of achieving the desired look. Over the course of the project, I extended three.js' standard materials with a custom TriPlanar shader which allows us to display a wide range of surfaces on a ring without pre-made UV coordinates.

A ring's surface can be brushed, or hammered, or visualize any futher number of techniques by uploading a set of textures in the backend.

Using [Substance Designer](https://www.adobe.com/products/substance3d/apps/designer.html), I also created the necessary normal and roughness maps for the various surface looks.

Another challenge was displaying diamonds on the ring. Achieving a satisfying look for a diamond - a special type of surface whose interaction with light is costly to even *approximate* in realtime 3d applications - was not easy.

In the end, I went with a custom implementation of [react-drei](https://github.com/pmndrs/drei)'s [MeshRefractionMaterial](https://drei.docs.pmnd.rs/shaders/mesh-refraction-material), and coupled this with a hand-ported version of the 'Kawase light-streak' post-processing effect (an example of which can be seen [here](https://github.com/XJINE/Unity_StarGlow)).

For a realistic look though, diamonds would need to be 'physically' inset into the ring. For this step, we decided to use boolean operations, cutting channels or individual settings into the ring - thankfully, [three-bvh-csg](https://github.com/gkjohnson/three-bvh-csg) was making great strides, and I was able to build atop this library's boolean results.

These boolean results were then processed further, merging geometry groups and juggling materials while keeping a close eye on performance.

I am still working on this project regularly, and fortunately, new challenges keep cropping up.

My oldest portfolio site was geared mostly towards 3D Art - since I'd never had the time to change things around since I started working as a web developer (and wordpress didn't survive one of the more recent php upgrades), it was now time to build anew.

Obviously there's always stuff to do:
My main gripe is that I'm currently still fetching content from a static .json instead of querying my hosted SQL database, but I'd also like to add user management, WYSIWYG editing, file uploads at some very much later date.

You are browsing the second iteration of this 'relaunch', the previous iteration can be seen by clicking 'Live Views' above. Browse the source on my github, also linked above.

[Fader360](https://fader360.vrgmnts.net) is an open-source 360-degree storytelling tool, developed as part of the EU-funded trans-european project [Mediaverse](https://mediaverse-project.eu).
By combining various types of media (video, images, text, audio) in a 360 degree environment, users create their own stories - linking individual chapters together to craft new narratives. 

[Mediaverse](https://mediaverse-project.eu) was a cooperation between various universities all over Europe, as well as broadcasters *Deutsche Welle*, among others.

One example of a *DW* project using *Fader360* can be viewed here: [NYC Women's March](https://fader360.vrgmnts.net/editor/view?project_id=83001b60-2125-4e53-983b-8e1f7cd845f2) - read more about it in *Deutsche Welle*'s blogpost: ["Immersive Citizen Journalism"](https://mediaverse-project.eu/2023/09/20/immersive-citizen-journalism/).

[VRagments](https://vragments.com)' [old version of fader](http://app.getfader.com) was rebuilt from scratch, using *react* and *react-three-fiber* (a wrapper for three.js).

In the frontend, pre-uploaded media assets are added to (or removed from) the scene-tree - combining them in new ways to tell a story. Here they can be annotated with text, color-themed, videos and audio can be set to play automatically or not, and clickable links to other scenes are set.

Various user preferences such as scene backgrounds, visible 3d grids, or scene order can be changed.

To display subtitles for the 360 background videos, the *srt* files provided were parsed and handled as *vtt* files .

 *Fader360*'s [backend](https://github.com/VRagments/fader360-backend) - created by colleagues - took care of asset uploads, linking these to Fader360 projects and newly created empty scenes. Login was handled with a mediaverse account, giving users access to other services within the project's infrastructure. 

Communication with the RESTful backend was handled with axios.

While the actual rebuild of the frontend took 4-5 months, during the much longer experimentation phase before that, I was also tasked with creating some prototype 3D environments to be used as backdrops for fader stories. A few of these can be seen below.

After completion of the EU project, fader360 was [open-sourced](https://github.com/VRagments/fader360-frontend) and can be freely used or developed further.

Feel free to login at [this fader dev backend instance](https://fader360.vrgmnts.net/users/login) with `jens@jbrandenburg.de` and password `!$V2&;+'i-EzrfF`, then follow [this link](https://fader360.vrgmnts.net/editor/edit?project_id=83d78046-e4dd-4679-a460-097ceb44104b) to directly enter the editor and click around, add assets to the scenes etc etc.

Unfortunately, Fader was not picked up commercially by anyone, so it's obviously rough around the edges yet.

textBlocks.text:
I had the honor of building the website which serves as a digital extension of ["Brotherland"](https://www.brotherland.info/), a photo project by [Martina Zaninelli](https://martinazaninelli.com/) and Thomas Jakobs. 

The project explores biographies of the so-called ['Vertragsarbeiter'](https://www.politische-bildung-brandenburg.de/ausstellungen/als-arbeitskraft-willkommen) after the fall of the GDR, and their plight amid steadily worsening racism and economic turmoil. 

The project was made possible with the support of the [Amadeu Antonio Stiftung](https://www.amadeu-antonio-stiftung.de/) and [Lichtenhagen im Gedächtnis](https://soziale-bildung.org/ueber_uns/politische-bildung/dokumentationszentrum-lichtenhagen-im-gedaechtnis/).

The site's ['virtual exhibits'](https://www.brotherland.info/html/virtual-exhibits/ve2.html) are inspired by the actual exhibit's various placards, while the large archive of [playable interviews](https://www.brotherland.info/html/interviews/intrvw_dhn01.html) and their transcriptions are linked to via QR code at actual exhibitions, and independantly browsable online.

Short [biographies](https://www.brotherland.info/html/bio.html) of the interviewees round things off. Since the website is to be used as a companion the the photo exhibit (the aforementioned QR links to audio), it is mobile ready.

Since the exhibit has been hosted in countries all over Europe, language can be switched between English and German.

The tech stack was entirely up to me, and since I felt react might be a bit too much, I went with [parcel](https://parceljs.org/) as bundler, and built some posthtml templates using [posthtml-expressions](https://github.com/posthtml/posthtml-expressions) and [posthtml-include](https://github.com/posthtml/posthtml-include).

Getting Martina's layout ideas to work as well as possible at wildly varying screen resolutions was a challenge, one that would have been lots harder without [tailwind CSS](https://tailwindcss.com/) and its many preset classes - I am relying heavily on css transforms in this case.

The gallery library is [simplelightbox](https://github.com/andreknieriem/simplelightbox). 

Check out the source code in the [github repo](https://github.com/cptSwing/brotherland).

textBlocks.text:
[Scrollmersive (archived link)](https://web.archive.org/web/20250208004340/https://www.scrollmersive.com/) - developed by Vragments GmbH - tells stories via scroll-driven animations of 3d objects.

These could be as simple as a rotating 3d mesh, or as complex as the camera following a path through a full 3d scene.

While scrolling, animations in the 3d environment can be triggered, as well as further information presented via html cards.

I handled a lot of the coding work on the [first iterations](https://3d.zdf.de/experiences/scooter/) of Scrollmersive (amusingly, this version is still hosted at zdf.de as they were testing the product early on)

The prototype was put together using vanilla [threeJS](https://www.threejs.org), leveraging it's CSS2DRenderer for in-scene information-cards.

There was a brief foray into using [babylonJS](https://www.babylonjs.com/) instead, but familiarity with threeJS won out in the end.

Later, I would transition more towards building the 3d content as projects came in.

[Deutsche Welle](https://www.dw.com) commissioned Vragments to build a 3d experience about Uyghur labor camps in China.

We worked closely with DW journalists and used provided satellite images and photos to recreate the scenery, and implemented a narrated camera path.

Due to a small budget and little time, we experimented with 'greybox' models, baked shadows, and simple posed characters to underscore DW's reporting.

(Unfortunately, the surviving [version on Wayback Machine](https://web.archive.org/web/20240221094741/https://www.scrollmersive.com/experiences/dw-uighur-sham-trials/) is not working correctly)

LOTS of 3d work in very little time was done for the award-winning Vragments-[Tagesspiegel](https://www.tagesspiegel.de/) cooperation ["Der BER im 3D-Modell"](https://interaktiv.tagesspiegel.de/lab/flughafen-ber-in-3d/).

I spent lots of time in 3D Studio Max on this, but also had the opportunity to add some custom material code to the codebase.

Do check out the post I wrote about that particular project [here!](/1/6)

Vragments has since pivoted away from Scrollmersive, but among other advertising content, I also created this (now archived & broken) [advertising SPA](https://web.archive.org/web/20230604065219/https://www.scrollmersive.com/) featuring an animated flightpath of a paper airplane down the page.

It would move to the front of some elements, and behind other elements during it's flight.

The site was again built using vanilla javascript and *threeJs*, as well as *tailwindcss*.

More recently, we were able to reuse a lot of the airport-related 3d content from the aforementioned Tagesspiegel application to showcase [Stöbich Fire Protection Solutions](https://som-stoebich.vrgmnts.net/).

Here I would do some more actual coding, setting up further animation triggers and shaders for highlighting (hidden) meshes, and working on an automatic timeline with chapters and varying animation speeds.

I also created some simple animations in 3D Studio Max.
I was moved off of this project after a while though, so the final version seen in the above link was completed by others.

I was too lazy to keep doing additions in my head, and since my gym app does not have this functionality, I built it myself.

Basically, it tells me how many weight plates of X kilograms to load on each side of a barbell (or a dumbbell, or..) in order to hit a target weight. It is what it is, but it's saved me quite some time.

Using chrome, it can be installed as a PWA on desktop or mobile as well.

Feel free to [clone the repo](https://github.com/cptSwing/plateCalc), and I have it running [here](https://www.jbrandenburg.de/bundles/plateCalc), you can install it right away.

Seeing as there is no triplanar mapping material for three.js which supports normal maps, I had previously thrown together a simpler version for [Ring Configurator](https://www.jbrandenburg.de/0/0).
Triplanar mapping is a technique to display textures on a model, disregarding it's texture coordinates. In effect, it can be used to quickly prototype models, or texture models according to the model's coordinate axes (ie top/bottom, left/right).

So I sat down again and started from scratch.

 For now, this uses [CustomShaderMaterial](https://github.com/FarazzShaikh/THREE-CustomShaderMaterial) to extend a THREE.MeshStandardMaterial. It supports basecolors, normal maps, and roughness maps for now, and is currently object-space only.

I'd love to build a world space shader sometime soon, but first I would like to get rid of the CSM dependency and move towards a v1 release.

Check out the source [here](https://github.com/cptSwing/three-triplanarmapping), and a test scene (built with react-three-fiber, still very unoptimized) [here](https://www.jbrandenburg.de/bundles/triplanar)

I built a little site to query [OpenHolidays'](https://www.openholidaysapi.org/) REST API for school- and public holidays, and find out when the best time to go on a vacation would be. You can pick up to five countries to show merged results for, and choose a time-range of up to 11 months.

In retrospect I could likely have saved a lot of time if I hadn't built the calender-view from scratch (and it's buggy still), but hey another learning experience.

Thanks to [Gradient.page](https://gradient.page/ui-gradients) as well (there's a switcher to cycle through different gradients in the top right).

textBlocks.text:
As part of EU-funded project [Digital Water City](http://www.digital-water.city/), Vragments worked with [Berliner Wasserbetriebe](https://www.bwb.de/) on a prototype of an Ipad app for [managing wells](https://www.digital-water.city/solution/mobile-application-for-asset-management-of-drinking-water-wells/), where I provided a few UI mockups.

More importantly, working again with Berliner Wasserbetriebe as well as [Kompetenzzentrum Wasser](https://kompetenz-wasser.de) and [Ecologic](https://www.ecologic.eu/de/16524), we built an [educational AR app](https://www.digital-water.city/solution/augmented-reality-ar-mobile-application-for-groundwater-visualization/) to inform about the groundwater, water filtration, and the water table in Berlin.

After a certain period of prototyping, we decided on an AR experience built in [Unity](https://unity.com/products/unity-engine), split into two segments: At first, the user'd be able to place a model of Berlin's geological layers via AR and step through these, as well as learn about the geology's history and groundwater's underground currents.

Then, several scenarios could be activated, where slices of terrain - usually centered around water purification plants or groundwater wells - could be placed via AR, and concepts such as filtration of water at the shore of lake Wannsee and others were presented in narrated animations.
Getting these right required close collaboration with BWB and KWB experts.

The [Youtube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4FmyfmdA9nk&t=30s) by Berliner Wasserbetriebe gives some further insight.
Since the [App store link](https://apps.apple.com/de/app/grundwasser-sichtbar-machen/id1537443189) might not be working anymore, here's a [mirrored version](https://apprecs.com/ios/1537443189/grundwasser-sichtbar-machen) that adds more context.

In this project I was responsible for anything graphics related.
I developed shaders in Unity, created animation timelines, cooked up a complicated render pipeline to be able to fuse on-screen meshes and postprocessing effects with the video stream coming in from the devices' camera.

I also spent an insane amount of time in 3D Studio Max, editing the very heavy and hard-to-work-with models of Berlin's geology, simplifying them for perfomance reasons, and turning non solid layers into solid geometry, ironing out a lot of bugs along the way.

Back in Unity, I worked on particle effects for water currents, and tied these together with the cartooney models we had decided on for the more detailed scenerios.

In conclusion, a rewarding project. Not much in the way of coding, but I got to touch nearly all other aspects of developing a realtime application or game.

Apparently it is still in use with educators at Berliner Wasserbetriebe, which is nice to know - check out the gallery below for more.

posts.title: BER Airport (Tagespiegel)
posts.subTitle: Interactive fly-through of BER airport's problems

textBlocks.text:
A cooperation between Vragments and Tagesspiegel, this project won us the ["Medienpreis Luft-](https://www.medienpreis-luft-und-raumfahrt.de/preisverleihung-2021/) [und Raumfahrt"](https://www.tagesspiegel.de/gesellschaft/medien/der-ber-im-3d-modell-tagesspiegel-gewinnt-medienpreis-luft-und-raumfahrt-2021-5126083.html).
Hendrik Lehmann and the team at Tagesspiegel also went on to win the ["Deutsche Reporterpreis" (Multimedia)](https://x.com/reporterforum/status/1467950400250732549).

A fast-paced project and a leap forward for scrollable-info-app Scrollmersive (I worked on, and wrote about it [here](http://www.jbrandenburg.de/0/4)), this project combined Tagesspiegel's journalism with Vragment's coding and 3d-modelling knowledge.

Tagespiegel [hosts the experience here](https://interaktiv.tagesspiegel.de/lab/flughafen-ber-in-3d/), do check it out. We are still quite proud of it.

On scroll, the camera follows a path along various stations in the airport, pausing and presenting information on construction faults or other complications that had made the airport a lot more expensive than planned, and had lengthened construction by many years.

Integration with the team at Tagesspiegel happened on several levels:
Design and code would be required to link up with the journalists regularly to keep tight control of the storyline.

Integration into the hosting environment at [tagesspiegel.de](https://www.tagesspiegel.de) was accomplished in parallel.

My focus would lie nearly exclusively on getting the 3d model of the BER into three.js at acceptable frame rates, creating some keyframe animations and working on mesh highlighting to support the narrative.

I opted for a "greybox" style with statically baked shadows with some lightly colored areas, to give the airport model visual texture (while not having to spend the time to give each and every element unique detail - which could distract from the story's narrative as well).

A much rougher version of the 3d model already existed, created for a joint VR project between Vragments and [Lorenz Matzat](https://web.archive.org/web/20160325040004/http://vrjournalist.de/ber-vr-entwicklertagebuch-seltsame-kopfbewegungen/). I had built this model as a freelancer a long time ago, from OSM maps and a ton of of reference photos - many even collected personally by the team on guided tours of the yet unopened airport.

In order to run well and look good in a browser window, however, lots of extra work was necessary.

Parts of the model had to be reorganized, texture assignments changed for three.js, scene-wide UV's created for lightmapping, as well some extra things for the aforementioned animations, or other more detailed looks at the various failing parts of the airport.

As touched upon above, we quickly decided to move away from a 'realistic' look and went with three.js's completely unlit MeshBasicMaterial for most surfaces.

The whole scene was UV-mapped to two large textures, and I baked shadow-maps and others - in many iterations - from within 3D Studio Max.
Layered together, these would give depth to the surfaces, defining crevices and highlighting edges.

Muted colors were added via another layer, or multiplied via exported vertex colors.
Some surfaces did use lit shading, most notably the glass areas, as well as some metals (airplane models, for instance).

This iterative process, with a close eye on texture size and performance (repeating/mirroring texture detail as much as possible, cutting extra geometry into meshes in order to use areas of the already baked texture, etc) constituted a large amount of the time I spent on the project.

StasiVR is another VR app for [Google Cardboard](https://vr.google.com/cardboard), built by [Vragments](http://www.vragments.com) and myself for [Deutschlandfunk Kultur](https://www.deutschlandfunkkultur.de/).

We worked closely with Jana Wuttke, a [radio journalist](https://www.deutschlandfunkkultur.de/verhoere-als-virtual-reality-ein-ganz-andere-form-von-100.html).

The app places the user in an authentic Stasi interrogation room, playing actual recordings of interrogations, and at times injecting necessary journalistic context.

Unfortunately, all app store links (Apple and Android) are long dead, but I hear the Android version can still be found on dodgy APK download sites.

Using dozens of photographs from the Stasi museum in Berlin as well as results from Jana's research, I faithfully recreated the interrogation room, within the usual constraints one encounters when developing for mobile VR.

Even so, the clear-cut and smaller scope allowed for some visual effects, such as the still-smoldering cigarette, as well as a post-processing effect to visually separate the two people in the room from the surroundings.

Most of objects in the scene are uniquely unwrapped and sparsely textured, for a "muted" look.

We brought everything together in the Unity game engine, which also provided a fairly easy way of deploying to mobile.

While Deutschlandfunk's blog seems to have been taken offline at some point, the minisite for the project can be still be accessed [here (Web archive)](https://web.archive.org/web/20231101111232/http://blogs.deutschlandradiokultur.de/stasiverhoer/).

Surprisingly, the embedded video on the archive site does still work and gives a good first impression.

Embedded next to this text is a very short teaser of an unfinished version.

Time and budget constraints meant that this project couldn't be developed into a more comprehensive app detailing the Stasi's interrogation methods, but teaching staff apparently still use it to this day.

For the project this VR app was a part of, Jana Wuttke and her colleague Martin Hartwig received the ["Crossmediapreis" 2018](https://web.archive.org/web/20221006030907/https://www.bremische-landesmedienanstalt.de/media-news/crossmediapreis-2018-unsere-preistraeger) from radio bremen, and were nominated for the ["Deutscher Radiopreis"](http://www.deutscher-radiopreis.de/radiopreis/gala_2017/nominierte/Nominiert-in-der-Kategorie-Beste-Innovation,innovation136.html) (2017, "Best innovation").

Here is another review by Deutschlandfunk: [Stasi-Verhör zum Nachempfinden](https://www.deutschlandfunk.de/virtual-reality-stasi-verhoer-zum-nachempfinden-100.html).

A mobile VR project about the continuing construction of the A-100 highway in and around Berlin, combining interviews, videos, and 360- as well as 3d content.

Created for [Rundfunk Berlin Brandenburg](http://www.rbb-online.de) and [Lorenz Matzat](https://www.datenjournalist.de/), as well as [Vragments](http://www.vragments.com).

Funding was also provided by [MIZ Babelsberg](https://www.miz-babelsberg.de/foerderung/allgemeines.html).

While working within the regular restrictions for mobile VR ten years ago, there were additional challenges like displaying the tunnel under the existing 3d model of the city, or splicing 2d sketches into 360 panoramic images.

Still, it was a very enjoyable project to be a part of, and collaborating with journalists is always fun.

The rbb has more information [here](https://www.rbb-online.de/unternehmen/der_rbb/profil/digitale_produkte/360vr/a100-vr.html), the apple [app store link](https://apps.apple.com/us/app/a100-vr/id1134883353?l=de&ls=1) even works.

Using Unity webplayer (not ultra fast, I'm afraid), the experience can be loaded in your browser as well: [Das A100-Virtual-Reality-Modell für den Browser](https://www.rbb24.de/politik/beitrag/2022/03/a100vr-web.html)

posts.title: U Stadtmitte (VR)
posts.subTitle: VR App at "Lange Nacht der Wissenschaften"

textBlocks.text:
[Technologiestiftung Berlin](https://www.technologiestiftung-berlin.de/), [BVG](http://www.bvg.de), [Vragments](http://www.vragments.com) and myself as freelancer built a mobile VR game for [Google Cardboards](https://vr.google.com/cardboard/).

It was first presented at [Lange Nacht der Wissenschaften](https://www.technologiestiftung-berlin.de/profil/blog/virtuell-durch-die-lange-nacht), and was built with the Unity game engine and 3d Studio Max.

Despite being a smaller project, it had some interesting challenges and restrictions.

I very much enjoyed being able to build the U-Bahn station "Stadtmitte" from BVG's original plans, for instance.

The combination of purely mobile platforms and VR imposed some very strict - and fun - limits on texture and geometry budgets.
VR applications render the 3d content twice, from slightly different perspectives, once for each eye.
Additionally, framerates are more important than usual as low or choppy FPS can cause vertigo or motion sickness.

Lighting and shadows were almost exlusively static/baked, with carefully edited lightmaps to give the best resolution at spots that most deserved it.

Most every surface you see is a tiling texture, with painstakingly adjusted texture atlasses to keep down texture fetches.

Hence, we got away with physically-based lighting - and the inclusion of normal maps in select parts of the map allowed for some local fine detail.

 Vragments published the source [here](https://github.com/VRagments/StadtmitteVR), I am afraid it's long gone from any app stores.

While I did a little work on one or two other titles during my time at [Promotion Software / Sixteen Tons Entertainment](https://www.sixteen-tons.de/), the bulk of my time was dedicated to real-time-strategy game ["Emergency 5" (credits)](https://www.mobygames.com/game/95782/emergency-5/credits/windows).

Admittedly a very work-intensive period in my life, but working in our small, tight-knit art-team was rewarding nonetheless.

Apart from modelling/texturing, I was tasked with reviewing and finalising models recieved by outsourced 3d modelers, creating and integrating cutscene animations, even some light team management.

As the team was moving to a new 3D engine, us in the art department were in constant touch with the graphics programmers, providing feedback and collaborating on features.

The following gallery showcases a couple of the models I created for this title.

textBlocks.text:
A collection of personal 3D and illustration projects I've taken on in my free time over the last decade or so.

Some were entries in pro-bono 3D art competitions ("The Escape", ["VROmega"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FIFnqfqciw)), some were part of my work for Half-Life 2 mod ["Fortress Forever"](https://store.steampowered.com/app/253530/Fortress_Forever/).
Some I've even managed to sell a couple of times (such as this model of the iconic WW2 [Soviet Mosin Nagant rifle](https://www.cgtrader.com/3d-models/military/gun/mosin-nagant-m1891-30-pbr-and-game-ready)).
And some I just wanted to try my hand at, or designed as a favor for friends.

My completion rate is sorely lacking, but that's to be expected I guess..

Slightly more context available when clicking through the gallery - I won't clutter this post with more unneeded text.

textBlocks.text:
While studying to be a Game Artist at Games Academy (their 2-year course "3D Art & Animation"), I created many 3d models. 

Some were indidivual assignments, many were also produced while working in larger group settings, working on more in-depth projects. A school for game art - many guns.

This will be more of an image dump.

METEÖR was the most successful project I worked on at Games Academy.

A 2 semester group effort with rookie coders, rookie game designers, rookie artists and rookie project-managers, we were introduced in a [RockPaperShotgun piece](https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/in-tune-with-the-audience-meteor), and were even nominated for "Best Game Design" alongside some heavy hitters at the [Animago Awards 2012](https://digitaleleinwand.de/2012/10/08/wer-macht-das-rennen-um-die-digitale-ehre-die-nominierten-zum-animago-award-2012-stehen-fest/).

I wanted to see if a configurator with lots of optional attachments etc could work.
I'm also experimenting with various workflows from 3DS Max to gltf to React-Three-Fiber, especially regarding vertex colors and using these as masks for coloring.
So I'm also editing shaders left and right..

Nothing is remotely finished, but I want to go back to it soon enough, a fun project.

Check it out [here](https://www.jbrandenburg.de/bundles/hovrboards/index.html)!

posts.subTitle: Started a collection of JS utilities

textBlocks.text:
So at first I built a little [tailwind](https://tailwindcss.com/) plugin to add css's clip-path [(inset() only, for now)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/basic-shape/inset) to the standard classes. The initial version is [here](https://github.com/cptSwing/cpts-tailwindcss-utilities) - I've yet to put it through it's paces and haven't actually tried any rounding, but it's currently doing it's job on this here website, for instance! 

 Usage is easy: `clip-inset-2`, `clip-inset-1/2` etc will clip content on all sides according to the same values as used in tailwind's `w-2` or `w-1/2` respectively (I am using the predefined 'width' values actually). 

`clip-inset-t` and `-r`, `-b`, `-l` clip the top, right, bottom left sides. `clip-inset-x` and `clip-inset-y` take care of horizontal and vertical sides.

I'm now adding more plugins, there is a mask-edges available now as well, equally beta but also in production use alread ;)

Admittedly, this started out as a way to duck beneath Vragment's build pipeline (eslint, rather) yelling at me about console.log's left in the code - but it has matured somewhat since then.

Calls to the DevConsole will be ignored if a production build is triggered, and in dev mode it can dump more thorough stacktraces, filter away some of the faff, has an option for deepcloning objects so they appear in the log as they do at runtime (slows things down, of course), and colors console output as well as tagging it with the filename it was called from (in VSCode).

[Check it out here](https://gist.github.com/cptSwing/0b63288955b30efda603f019ccf00c2c) . Some things will likely break outside of a specific environment - I had to adjust how webpack outputs sourcemaps, for instance - so obviously YMMV.
